attributes.action: No energy price cap rises before 2028 when government energy loans are repaid.

attributes.action: Reconsider the Chancellor’s approach for tackling spiralling energy costs.
attributes.background:
The governments approach to tackling the energy cost crisis is badly thought out and should be reconsidered:
- households that don’t need a rebate cannot opt out and allow more targeted support for those in need
- there’s no support for small business
- it does nothing for long term energy issues
attributes.additional_details:
As one of the wealthiest countries in the world it is absolutely scandalous that people are having to make the choice between heating and eating.  Although the measures that the government has proposed will help some households stay out of fuel poverty, many will still be left with a stark choice. 

Support for energy poverty needs to be increased and far better targeted. Support for small businesses needs to happen. Investment in long term renewable energy security must increase rapidly.

attributes.action: Stop energy suppliers overcharging direct debit customers to build up credit.
attributes.background: Stop Energy suppliers overcharging customers who pay by monthly direct debit. They set payments to much higher than the actual cost of usage and give customers no control over how much money they take because they tell us we should be in credit for winter.
attributes.additional_details: It's unfair to be expected to pay hundreds of pounds more than the actual cost of your annual consumption and then have to wait to be refunded. Some consumers may be happy to pay their bills in this way but others like myself are not. I would like to have the option to pay for my actual usage every month, no more no less. But it seems that most energy suppliers don't give you that choice anymore and direct debit customers are an easy target for overcharging.

rejection.details:
The way that individual energy suppliers calculate direct debits and review these is a matter for individual suppliers, and Ofgem is responsible for protecting consumers from bad practice.

All suppliers must already take all reasonable steps to ensure that your direct debit payments are based on the best available information, and must explain why payments need to change: https://www.ofgem.gov.uk/system/files/docs/2019/03/direct_debit_factsheet_feb_2019.pdf

Ofgem says that by providing regular meter readings to your supplier you can make sure you are only paying for the energy that you have used.

If you are unhappy with how your supplier has set your direct debits you could complain about this. Ofgem has published a guide on how to complain, which you might find helpful: https://www.ofgem.gov.uk/consumers/household-gas-and-electricity-guide/complain-about-your-gas-or-electricity-bill-or-supplier

attributes.action: Improve the thermal performance of heritage buildings by changing the glass
attributes.background: I would like the Government to change the existing planning law to allow the use of Vacuum glass which will help reduce energy, prevent heat loss and reduce CO2 emissions.
attributes.additional_details: With global warming and the need to reduce CO2 emissions I want the Government to allow all homeowners the opportunity to change their existing single glazed windows and doors into thermally efficient windows and doors that will save the homeowner’s heating bills and in turn reduce energy costs which will also reduce CO2 emissions

rejection.details:
Under planning law listed building consent will normally be required where a listed building is to be altered in a way that effects its character as a building of special architectural or historic interest, but decisions about granting consent is a matter for individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

Historic England has published guidance on the care, repair and upgrading of traditional windows which states that “historic windows of interest should be retained wherever possible using careful matching repair" and that their complete replacement "should be a last resort and is rarely necessary” but, again, decisions about what alterations to grant consent for are a matter for individual planning authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

attributes.action: Replace the statues of slave owners with solar panels
attributes.background: Statues of slave owners should be torn down and replaced with solar panels or other forms of sustainable energy production. Perhaps plaques could be erected also explaining why these statues where torn down.
attributes.additional_details: The celebration of slave ownership and systemic racism should have no place in this country - even if these people where rich and powerful in other significant ways. The celebration of slave ownership and systemic racism also should have no place in this country if the prime minister and his cabinet claims to support the Black Lives Matter movement. The erection of solar panels in their place would assist battling the climate emergency (an issue that the UK has done very little against).

rejection.details:
Decisions about individual historical monuments, statues, plaques and street names are a matter for the local authority in which they are located and private landowners, not the UK Government or Parliament.

If you want to raise concerns about a particular historical monument or statue you should contact your local authority about this.

The Local Government Association has published an advice note to help councils work to ensure all sections of the community feel heard by decision-makers and each other: https://www.local.gov.uk/topics/community-safety/statues

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Encourage and support the removal of memorials that glorify the slave trade: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/325449

Create an advisory board to review public statues and decide on their removal: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/325673

attributes.action: COVID-19 economic rescue plans must be green
attributes.background:
Coronavirus and climate change are the biggest challenges facing a generation.

Emergency financing must be used to build a sustainable economy which supports our health and wellbeing and drives growth, providing new jobs and opportunities across the UK for our generation and those of the future.
attributes.additional_details:
In 2019, Parliament declared a climate change emergency. 

The government committed to net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, pledging investment in clean energy solutions and green infrastructure and forecasting that the low carbon economy ‘could grow 11 per cent per year between 2015 and 2030, four times faster than the projected growth of the economy as a whole’.

The government must invest emergency funds in green and reproductive sectors including health, social care and public services.

attributes.action: Stop any planned electricity blackouts this winter
attributes.background: The government needs to introduce legislation to stop the National Grid from planning electricity blackouts due to supply shortages, by legally requiring all industry and retail sectors to power down all non-essential electricity usage during peak hours.
attributes.additional_details:
Industry and retail use colossal amounts of electricity, and are responsible for vast amounts of irresponsible wastage, like leaving machinery running, and leaving lighting and heating on unnecessarily. 

The general public should never be subjected to having planned electricity blackouts imposed on them, ever.

We all have a part to play in energy conservation, but industry and retail should bear a large part of that responsibility, and be legally required to do so by the government.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. National Grid is independent of the UK Government and Parliament, so any decision on managing electricity load is a decision for them. 

You might be interested to know National Grid already have a scheme for managing demand from businesses, which you can read about here

https://www.nationalgrideso.com/industry-information/balancing-services/demand-side-response-dsr

attributes.action: Raise LHA in line with inflation in 2023.

rejection.details:

attributes.action: Ensure Equality for Northern Ireland with Energy Support Payments.

to centrally confirm a payment date by early December for essential assistance before Christmas.
attributes.additional_details:
